title: Wednesday, 7th February, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:04 am

Manxish Morning

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Anyway, this bit caught my eye .....

BE11:12am

Mrs May should trust her instinct that the shrinking of manufacturing coincided with the emergence of a more divided Britain. She should come up with an industrial strategy which recognises that too much surplus is being redirected from enhancing productivity to speculative activity.

This would see a wider national interest test for takeovers; require a higher threshold than just the majority of shares to buy a company; and restrict short-term investors such as hedge funds from having a vote in mergers. Such measures would allow ministers to extract concrete commitments from corporates for the benefit of wider society. Other nations offer firms a degree of protection from hostile takeovers without damaging investment flows. It’s time that Britain did too.

Londonbus @red - I'm paid in USD here. The weaker the GBP the better...
BE11:12am

.... "restrict short-term investors such as hedge funds from having a vote in mergers"

11:12 am
BE11:12am

"Pft", I thought. "How ludicrous." But then .....

red @BE prob sensible but dangerous ground. and sensible isnt whats mkts are about. making money for parts is what its about.
BE11:13am

.... I mean, sure, definitions of short termism would be impossible. But why not close the shareholder register at the day before the announcement?

BE11:13am

For voting, I mean.

FATDAZ we should certainly have an industrial strategy but whether its should concern itself with those items is questionable
Arash Massoudi, FT @BE - there has been a push from this from some pretty big corporate name .... "restrict short-term investors such as hedge funds from having a vote in mergers" ...
11:13 am

Here comes Goodbody.

BE11:17am

Smurfit Kappa has reported Q4 EBITDA of €351m which is slightly ahead (1%) of both our forecasts and consensus of €346m. Key variances were a stronger than expected outturn in Europe (a reflection of growing momentum on cost recovery) and lower central costs, which more than offset a challenging final quarter for the Americas (currency and slower volume growth in some countries), see enclosed detailed tables. Also of note is the 12% increase in the final dividend to 64.5c, ahead of our expectations of 60c.

pfd @rwl cable or FTSE?
Soundbuy Smurfit Q4 was stonking.............
Londonbus @pfd - I hope so! Mate of mine is buying a flat in Sheffield. Holding USD.
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Of note is the commentary around recent announcements for €60/tonne increases
in European kraftliner / testliner prices, “the majority of which will be implemented
in February”. Given this momentum in Europe coupled with an expected improvement in the Americas (supported by restructuring and recent investments)
we are comfortable with our recently increased FY18 EBITDA forecasts of €1.4bn, which is slightly ahead of consensus. As Smurfit Kappa is the most geared to such positive pricing dynamics, it continues to be our preferred pick in the sector.

BE11:17am

Europe good:

rwl @pfd - sorry - I meant ftse - (lost the link!)
BE11:18am

In terms of the European operations, the key points are: (i) Steady mid-single
digit corrugated box volume growth for three consecutive quarters; (ii) further
recovery on corrugated box prices which we believe are now +5% from the lows at
the start of 2017; (iii) this has all led to an inflection point for margins which were
up circa 140bps in Q4 (-10bps Q1, -170bps Q2 and -30bps Q3).

11:17 am
BE11:18am

America bad:

BE11:18am

Compared to our expectations the Americas had a more challenging final quarter,
a function of higher recovered fibre prices, adverse currency movements, higher
imported containerboard prices into Latin America where the business is short and
a slowdown in volume growth. The latter is reflected in FY corrugated volume
growth of 2% versus a consistent 3% for Q1-Q3. Encouragingly management has
indicated that trends have improved in the YTD. In addition, the region will benefit
from restructuring measures (incurred a €12m charge in Q4) and recent
investments which will decrease the group’s dependence on containerboard
imports into Latin America. All of which supports a better outturn in 2018.

BE11:18am

(But improving.)

FATDAZ RE FTSE 6450 is mid term target in my model though I think 6690 might more realistsic near term
11:19 am

pfd think i'm a scaled in buyer at 7000 and below. div yield supports and i don't see UK rates getting up very far in the next few years
BE11:20am

SKG’s Q4 results mark an inflection point in the profitability of its European operations. This reflects on-going improvement in box prices, driven by strong demand and tight containerboard supplies. With the latest increases in containerboard prices set to be implemented, further box price rises are likely. This should result in positive earnings momentum during 2018. This potential, combined with the options provided through the company’s capital allocation strategy, is not fully reflected in the valuation. We reiterate our ‘Outperform’ rating and 3300c price target.

BE11:42am

Here's JP Morgan to summarise.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Redrow interim results are ahead of our expectations. Revenue is a 4% beat vs. our estimate and the operating margin is 20bps head of our estimate, driving a 5% beat on operating profit. New JV profits and a reduction in interest and the tax rate mean the beat at EPS is 10%. The interim dividend has been increased by 50% to 9p, comfortably ahead of our 7p estimate. Bloomberg consensus looks for only 29% growth y/y in the full year dividend. The commentary on current trading reads well – while the statement says reservations in the first five weeks of 2018 have been in line with last year (which we assume has been adjusted for site numbers). While there’s no commentary on the second half sales rate, the order book at 31 Dec was up 5% y/y, vs. +3% y/y last time we heard in November. While it’s slightly difficult to call what is likely to happen to full year results based on the disclosure we have so far, we see some scope for upside to full year earnings estimates. We expect full year dividend estimates to move up to reflect the H1 beat.

BE11:43am

Headline financials: We set out H1 numbers vs. our estimates in Table 1 below. The disclosure on volumes and ASP in the statement includes JVs, making it slightly harder to comp on a y/y basis but, on first view, ASP looks to be 9% stronger than we assumed (£330k). While overall completions are broadly flat y/y, it looks like wholly owned completions are down slightly, and more completions are coming through the JV line. The gross margin is slightly below last year and our estimate (at 24.5% vs. 24.8%); however, we assume this is likely to be due to a higher proportion of social units in the mix in H1, to which Redrow assigns a slower gross margin. The operating margin is, however, 20pbs better than our estimate at 19.7%, as admin expenses have fallen to 4.8% of sales, from 5.5% last year.

Londonbus I remember being on here during 2008 when the housebuilders were on the verge of insolvency. How times change.
BE11:43am

And Cenkos.

Headline financials: We set out H1 numbers vs. our estimates in Table 1 below. The disclosure on volumes
and ASP in the statement includes JVs, making it slightly harder to comp on a y/y basis but, on first view,
ASP looks to be 9% stronger than we assumed (£330k). While overall completions are broadly flat y/y, it
looks like wholly owned completions are down slightly, and more completions are coming through the JV
line. The gross margin is slightly below last year and our estimate (at 24.5% vs. 24.8%); however, we assume
this is likely to be due to a higher proportion of social units in the mix in H1, to which Redrow assigns a
slower gross margin. The operating margin is, however, 20pbs better than our estimate at 19.7%, as admin
expenses have fallen to 4.8% of sales, from 5.5% last year.

BE11:44am

Wait, that's not Cenkos. This is.

FATDAZ @London bus doesn't seem that long ago does it
BE11:44am

 The slight sting in the tail of its AGM IMS last November (the last official word from management) which highlighted a
slowing in sales “in recent weeks” has proved a mere blip. Interims are superb in just about every respect.
 Legal completions are +14% at 2811 and ASP rose 9% to £330k (largely mix driven by greater southern completions
including the first sales out of Colindale gardens and its Croydon JV. Revenues grew 20% to £890m.
 Operating margins of 19.7% edged up by 20bps courtesy of a very tight operating expenses line (up only 5%) and
consequent PBT of £176m rose 26%, matched at EPS with 39.5p. The level of ‘beat’ over my estimates was c13% -
impressive.
 Not content with that the DPS is lifted 50% to 9p and net debt at £35m is c£45m below my expectation. Management
is guiding year end debt only “modestly” higher than this. Land creditors at £382m are below last year’s level too despite
increasing the current lands bank to 27,600 plots (up 1,500) and the forward land (unconsented) to 31,800 (up 5,400).
Balance sheet inventories rose 11% to £2.15bn.
 Reservations taken in the period increased 10% on a LFL basis to £795m whilst average outlets rose by 5 to 127. The
creditable pull through production to sales has left the Dec-17 order book at a record £1.05bn, +5%. Sales reservation
after 5 weeks of H2 are said to be “in line with the strong comparable period last year”.
 Redrow should beat my Fy18 forecasts of £342m/ 75.9p EPS and consensus £350m/ 77.9p. Against my number I’d
make an early stab at 6%-7% ahead of the meeting at 9am.
I won’t lie; I was beginning to feel a bit twitchy with Redrow as my last remaining Buy in the sector as my long standing bull
sector stance has progressively shifted to neutral since Q3-Q4/17. If nothing else these results have bought me some time
and Redrow shareholders some hearty relief.

And Barclays.

BE11:49am

The Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) government has in recent days promulgated a draconian new mining code. The new code was passed by both houses of Parliament last week but still has to be signed by the president before it becomes law. According to press reports (e.g. Bloomberg 31 Jan), the proposed changes include raising royalties on base metals and gold from 2.5% to 5%, on cobalt from 2% to 5-10% (depending on whether it’s classified as a strategic mineral), raising the obligatory state ownership of mining assets to 10% and imposing a 50% super profits tax on all “profits” (undefined) where a commodity price is more than 25% above the assumed long-run price in the bankable feasibility study for each mine. In addition the new code requires previous 10-year standstill agreements (protecting mines from changes in fiscal regime for 10 years) to be cancelled, for the mines to comply with new arrangements immediately and be replaced with 5-year standstill agreements. The new mining code has not yet been published by the DRC government, so there is still significant uncertainty around the specific detail of the mining code but is likely the key driver for Glencore (-8% vs peer at -2 to -4.5%) and Randgold’s (-10% vs peers -3 to -5%) share price underperformance over the past week – so largely already priced in by the market, in our view.

BE11:56am

Although we are surprised to see a non-exec becoming joint CEO, it will allow the current banking team to continue to focus on the bank, with David van der Walt and Richard Wainwright to be joint heads of the bank while Ciaran Whelan (Currently head of the Private Bank and also joint head of global banking) will be head of risk, a key banking function.
There will also now be a dedicated group FD, Kim McFarland (currently COO and CFO of Asset Management), a welcome change, in our view. The new group chairman to replace Fani Titi is Perry Crosthwaite (an independent non-exec director since 2010, with significant experience in investment banking and of the Investec group). Steve Elliott remains head of Wealth & Investments while Asset Management will be headed up jointly by John Green and Mimi Ferrini, with Hendrik du Toit only handing over in
September 2018.
Overall, these changes look sensible to us, although we would watch closely the performance of joint heads, both divisionally and at group level. Although Fani Titi has significant business experience and has been involved with Investec since 2004, he does not have operational banking experience, and it is a big change from the current
hands-on and very experienced banker, Stephen Koseff. However, we note the substantial time to hand-over also reduces the risk, with Stephen Koseff and Bernard Kantor stepping down only on 1 October and Glynn Burger remaining until 31 March 2019. We think improvement of the bank's profitability is key to a re-rating of the stock and we will be analysing whether the new team can deliver improvements in metrics such as the bank ROE.
